name: Sam Phillips
description:
'''Samuel Cornelius Phillips''' (January 5, 1923 â€“ July 30, 2003) was an American disc jockey, songwriter and record producer. He was the founder of [[Sun Records]] and [[Sun Studio]] in [[Memphis, Tennessee]], where he produced recordings by [[Elvis Presley]], [[Roy Orbison]], [[Jerry Lee Lewis]], [[Carl Perkins]], [[Johnny Cash]], and [[Howlin' Wolf]]. Phillips played a major role in the development of [[rock and roll]] during the 1950s, launching the career of Presley. In 1969, he sold Sun to [[Shelby Singleton]].

Phillips was the owner and operator of radio stations in Memphis; Florence, Alabama; and [[Lake Worth Beach, Florida]]. He was also an early investor in the [[Holiday Inn]] chain of hotels and an advocate for racial equality, helping to break down racial barriers in the [[music industry]].
